The **economy of Algeria** deals with Algeria's current and structural
economic situation. Currently, Algeria has a mixed economy. Since independence
in 1962, Algeria has launched major economic projects to build up a dense
industrial base. However, despite these major achievements (roads, freeways,
universities, hospitals, factories, housing, metro and tramway systems, etc.),
the Algerian economy has gone through various stages of turbulence.

In the 1980s, the Algerian economy experienced major difficulties. The oil
counter-shock of 1986 dealt a heavy blow to a virtually rentier economy,
during the period of anti-scarcity and stabilization plans. In the early
1990s, Algeria embarked on a series of structural reforms, making the
transition to a market economy a reality.

In 2012, the Algerian economy remains highly dependent on hydrocarbon rents,
which represent the country's main source of revenue, without having succeeded
in diversifying and establishing internationally competitive
industrialization.

The 2017 report on Algeria by business intelligence and consultancy firm
Oxford Business Group (OGB), highlights the efforts devoted by the country to
strengthening and diversifying its economy against the backdrop of falling oil
prices. The report highlights the growing contribution of the private sector
to GDP, in particular the role of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs)
supported by new measures; as well as the financial services sector, which has
seen positive developments such as the introduction of online payments.

Despite the efforts made, the country still faces a number of short-term
problems, including the need to diversify the economy, strengthen political,
economic and financial reforms, improve the business climate and reduce social
inequality between regions, in order to achieve better economic growth.
Algeria has the triple leverage of energy, mining and agriculture to
contribute, in the long term, to containing the supply crises in energy, rare
earths (minerals useful for technology) and food.

Published in 2023, the World Bank's report on the Algerian economy calls for
the acceleration of institutional and micro-economic reforms, and paints a
positive picture for the country's economy. The World Bank notes that the
promulgation in 2022 of the new investment law and the publication of its
implementing regulations, the abolition in 2020 of the 51/49 rule for non-
strategic sectors, and the publication of the new hydrocarbons law in 2019 are
positive steps, but must tackle the ecosystem, including paralyzing
bureaucracy, with greater visibility in socio-economic policy.

Continued implementation of government structural reform programs, creating
greater openness to the private sector, improving the economy’s
competitiveness, and strengthening investment in human capital are all
essential to the flourishing and resilience of the Algerian economy.

The total imports and exports on the eve of the French invasion (in 1830) did
not exceed £175,000. By 1850, the figures had reached £5,000,000; in 1868,
£12,000,000; in 1880, £17,000,000; and in 1890, £20,000,000. From this point
progress was slower and the figures varied considerably year by year. In 1905
the total value of the foreign trade was £24,500,000. About five-sixths of the
trade is with or via France, into which country several Algerian goods have
been admitted duty-free since 1851, and all since 1867. French goods, except
sugar, have been admitted into Algeria without payment of duty since 1835.
After the 1892 increase of the French minimum tariff which applied to Algeria
for the first time, foreign trade greatly diminished.[_citation needed_]

GDP per capita grew 40% in the 1960s, reaching a peak growth of 538% in the
1970s. Growth collapsed to 9.7% in the turbulent 1980s. Failure of timely
reforms by successive governments caused the current GDP per capita to shrink
by 28% in the 1990s.

Burdened with a heavy foreign debt, Algiers concluded a one-year standby
arrangement with the International Monetary Fund in April 1994 and the
following year signed onto a three-year extended fund facility which ended 30
April 1998. In March 2006, Russia agreed to erase $4.74 billion of Algeria's
Soviet-era debt during a visit by President Vladimir Putin to the country, the
first by a Russian leader in half a century. In return, president Abdelaziz
Bouteflika agreed to buy $7.5 billion worth of combat planes, air-defence
systems and other arms from Russia, according to the head of Russia's state
arms exporter Rosoboronexport.

Some progress on economic reform, Paris Club debt reschedulings in 1995 and
1996, and oil and gas sector expansion contributed to a recovery in growth
since 1995, reducing inflation to approximately 1% and narrowing the budget
deficit. Algeria's economy has grown at about 4% annually since 1999. The
country's foreign debt has fallen from a high of $28 billion in 1999 to its
current level of $5 billion. The spike in oil prices in 1999–2000 and the
government's tight fiscal policy, as well as a large increase in the trade
surplus and the near tripling of foreign exchange reserves has helped the
country's finances. However, an ongoing drought, the after effects of the
floods of 10 November 2001 and an uncertain oil market made prospects for
2002-03 more problematic. The government has pledged to continue its efforts
to diversify the economy by attracting foreign and domestic investment outside
the energy sector.

Hotel Zianides in Tlemcen.

President Bouteflika has announced sweeping economic reforms, which, if
implemented, will significantly restructure the economy. Still, the economy
remains heavily dependent on volatile oil and gas revenues. The government has
continued efforts to diversify the economy by attracting foreign and domestic
investment outside the energy sector, but has had little success in reducing
high unemployment and improving living standards. Other priority areas include
banking reform, improving the investment environment, and reducing government
bureaucracy.

The government has announced plans to sell off state enterprises: sales of a
national cement factory and steel plant have been completed and other
industries are up for offer. In 2001, Algeria signed an Association Agreement
with the European Union. In June 1987, Algeria started accession negotiations
for entry into the World Trade Organization, but negotiations ceased in 2014.

In the 2000s the country enjoyed several years of strong economic performance,
with solid non-hydrocarbon growth, low inflation, an overall budget surplus
and a positive trade balance.

generated_detailed_content: On the eve of the French invasion in 1830, Algeria's total imports and exports were remarkably limited, amounting to no more than £175,000. This modest level of foreign trade reflected the largely agrarian and subsistence-based economy of the region prior to colonial rule, with limited integration into global markets. However, the subsequent decades witnessed a significant expansion in Algeria's trade activities. By 1850, the total value of trade had surged dramatically to £5,000,000, signaling the initial impact of French colonial policies aimed at integrating Algeria into the French economic sphere and exploiting its resources and agricultural potential. This upward trajectory continued throughout the latter half of the nineteenth century. In 1868, the value of foreign trade had more than doubled from 1850 levels, reaching £12,000,000. By 1880, it had further increased to £17,000,000, reflecting both the expansion of export commodities such as agricultural products and raw materials, and the growth of imports necessary to support colonial infrastructure and settler populations. The decade following saw continued growth, with trade totals reaching £20,000,000 by 1890. Despite this growth, the pace began to slow, and annual fluctuations became more pronounced, indicating the volatility of the colonial economy and its dependence on external markets and policies. By 1905, the total value of Algeria's foreign trade stood at approximately £24,500,000. Throughout this period, France dominated Algeria’s trade relations, conducting about five-sixths of all foreign trade either directly or through French intermediaries. This dominance was reinforced by preferential trade arrangements established between the two countries. Since 1851, various Algerian goods had been admitted duty-free into France, a policy that was extended in 1867 to include all goods. Conversely, French goods, with the notable exception of sugar, were admitted into Algeria without duty from as early as 1835. These preferential tariffs effectively integrated Algeria into the French economic system as a supplier of raw materials and a market for French manufactured goods. However, the trade relationship experienced disruption following the increase in the French minimum tariff in 1892, which applied to Algeria for the first time. This tariff hike led to a significant decline in foreign trade, highlighting the vulnerability of Algeria’s economy to changes in French economic policy. The imposition of higher tariffs reduced the competitiveness of Algerian exports and increased the cost of imports, thereby constraining trade volumes and economic growth. Moving into the post-independence era, Algeria’s economic performance exhibited marked fluctuations. During the 1960s, the country experienced a notable growth in GDP per capita, increasing by 40%. This growth was driven by efforts to modernize the economy and expand industrial and agricultural production following independence in 1962. The 1970s saw an even more dramatic surge, with GDP per capita peaking at a growth rate of 538%. This extraordinary expansion was largely fueled by the nationalization of hydrocarbon resources in 1971 and the subsequent boom in oil and gas revenues, which provided substantial fiscal resources for development projects and social programs. However, the economic momentum faltered in the 1980s amid a period of turbulence marked by declining oil prices, external debt accumulation, and structural inefficiencies. Growth collapsed to a mere 9.7%, reflecting the challenges of managing a rentier economy heavily reliant on volatile hydrocarbon exports. The 1990s were particularly difficult; due to failures in government reform efforts and the impact of internal conflict, Algeria’s GDP per capita shrank by 28%. This contraction underscored the vulnerability of the economy to both domestic instability and external shocks. Data from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) provides a detailed picture of Algeria’s economic trends during this period. In 1980, Algeria’s gross domestic product at market prices was estimated at 162,500 million Algerian dinars, with a US dollar exchange rate of 3.83 dinars per dollar. The inflation index stood at 9.30 (using the year 2000 as the base 100), and per capita income was approximately 18.51% of that of the United States. By 1985, GDP had increased to 291,600 million dinars, but the exchange rate had depreciated to 4.77 dinars per dollar, inflation had risen to 14, and per capita income had declined to 15.55% of the US level. The downward trend continued into 1990, with GDP reaching 554,400 million dinars, the exchange rate weakening further to 12.19 dinars per dollar, inflation climbing to 22, and per capita income falling to 10.65% of the US benchmark. The mid-1990s saw a dramatic depreciation of the dinar and soaring inflation. By 1995, GDP had ballooned to 2,004,990 million dinars, but the exchange rate had plummeted to 47.66 dinars per dollar, inflation had surged to 73, and per capita income had dropped to just 5.39% of US levels. The year 2000 marked further challenges, with GDP at 4,123,514 million dinars, an exchange rate of 75.31 dinars per dollar, inflation at 100, and per capita income at 5.17%. By 2005, the economy showed signs of stabilization with GDP reaching 7,493,000 million dinars, a slightly improved exchange rate of 73.44 dinars per dollar, inflation at 114, and a modest recovery in per capita income to 7.43% of the US level. For purchasing power parity comparisons, the US dollar was exchanged at 70.01 Algerian dinars as of May 24, 2007, and average wages in 2007 ranged between approximately US$18 and US$22 per day, reflecting modest income levels in the broader population. In response to mounting economic difficulties and heavy foreign debt burdens, Algeria engaged with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in the 1990s. In April 1994, the country concluded a one-year standby arrangement with the IMF aimed at stabilizing the economy and managing debt obligations. This was followed in 1995 by the signing of a three-year extended fund facility with the IMF, which lasted until April 30, 1998. These arrangements were part of broader efforts to implement structural adjustment programs and fiscal reforms to restore macroeconomic stability. A significant development in Algeria’s external debt management occurred in March 2006 during Russian President Vladimir Putin’s visit—the first by a Russian leader in 50 years. Russia agreed to forgive $4.74 billion of Algeria’s Soviet-era debt, a considerable relief for the Algerian economy. In exchange, Algerian President Abdelaziz Bouteflika committed to purchasing $7.5 billion worth of military equipment from Russia, including combat aircraft and air-defense systems, as reported by Rosoboronexport. This debt-for-equipment deal underscored the strategic and economic ties between the two countries. Economic recovery since the mid-1990s was supported by a combination of factors, including economic reforms, debt rescheduling agreements with the Paris Club in 1995 and 1996, and expansion in the oil and gas sectors. These efforts contributed to reducing inflation to approximately 1%, narrowing the budget deficit, and fostering a more stable macroeconomic environment. Since 1999, Algeria’s economy has grown at an average annual rate of about 4%, while foreign debt decreased substantially from a peak of $28 billion in 1999 to roughly $5 billion in more recent years. The spike in oil prices during 1999–2000, combined with tight fiscal policies, bolstered the economy by increasing the trade surplus and expanding foreign exchange reserves. Despite these gains, Algeria faced ongoing challenges in the early 2000s. The years 2002 and 2003 were marked by environmental and economic difficulties, including a persistent drought and the aftermath of devastating floods on November 10, 2001. Additionally, uncertainty in global oil markets posed risks to the country’s hydrocarbon-dependent economy. In response, the government pledged to diversify the economy by attracting both foreign and domestic investment in sectors beyond energy. President Bouteflika announced sweeping economic reforms aimed at restructuring the economy to reduce dependence on volatile oil and gas revenues, although such dependence remained high. Efforts to diversify the economy have met with limited success in addressing high unemployment rates and improving living standards. Priority areas for reform have included banking sector modernization, improving the investment climate, and reducing bureaucratic obstacles that hinder private sector development. The government also announced plans to privatize state-owned enterprises, successfully selling a national cement factory and a steel plant, with additional industries slated for sale. These privatization efforts aimed to stimulate economic efficiency and attract investment. In terms of international economic integration, Algeria signed an Association Agreement with the European Union in 2001, reflecting a commitment to closer trade and political ties with Europe. Earlier, in June 1987, Algeria had begun accession negotiations to join the World Trade Organization (WTO); however, these negotiations were ultimately suspended in 2014, reflecting ongoing challenges in meeting WTO requirements and domestic economic priorities. Throughout the 2000s, Algeria experienced several years of strong economic performance characterized by solid growth in non-hydrocarbon sectors, low inflation rates, a budget surplus, and a positive trade balance. This period of relative stability and growth demonstrated the potential benefits of economic reforms and prudent fiscal management, even as the country continued to grapple with the structural challenges inherent in its resource-dependent economy.

a per capita basis. The estimated real growth rate is 2.6%, down from 3.4% in
2022. In 2017 industry accounted for 39.3%% of GDP, services constituted

After having virtually eliminated external debt before 2013, the drop

been only partly offset by spending cuts. Consequently, government debt has
increased to more than 30% of GDP. Inflation has remained at 3-6% on average
for 2013–17. However, the economy remains highly dependent on hydrocarbons,
which represent 89% of total exports; a continued slowdown of global energy
demand has significantly put pressure on Algeria's fiscal and external
positions.
